mainEntity.name: Are Myrtle Beach home prices really dropping in 2025?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, prices are stabilizing after years of sharp increases. Median home values are slightly lower than 2024 but remain well above pre-pandemic levels.

mainEntity.name: Is it a good time to sell my Myrtle Beach home?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes—if you price strategically. Homes listed within local comp ranges are still selling within 2–3 months, especially in Carolina Forest and Market Common.

mainEntity.name: Should I wait until 2026 to buy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Waiting rarely pays off in coastal markets. Myrtle Beach offers long-term value, and even modest appreciation can outpace savings from lower future rates.

mainEntity.name: What areas of Myrtle Beach hold value best?

acceptedAnswer.text: Neighborhoods like Market Common, Carolina Forest, and Surfside Beach consistently outperform due to newer construction, flood safety, and strong amenities.

mainEntity.name: Will interest rates lower housing demand in Myrtle Beach?

acceptedAnswer.text: Higher rates have slowed some second-home buyers, but migration from northern states continues to support steady demand across the Grand Strand.

mainEntity.name: Will Myrtle Beach home prices drop in 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: In 2026, most changes in the Myrtle Beach housing market are expected to appear as increased negotiation rather than widespread price drops. Buyers may see more concessions, price adjustments on overpriced homes, and longer days on market. Well-located and well-maintained homes on the Grand Strand are still likely to hold value, while homes that miss pricing or condition expectations may lag.

mainEntity.name: What mortgage rate trends are expected for 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: Mortgage rates in 2026 are projected to improve modestly compared to recent years, potentially settling closer to the mid-6% range. Even small rate changes can meaningfully affect buyer affordability. In coastal South Carolina, buyers should also account for insurance, HOA dues, and total monthly housing costs when planning a purchase.

mainEntity.name: What are the FHA loan limits for Myrtle Beach in 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: For 2026, the FHA one-unit loan limit for Horry County, which includes Myrtle Beach, Conway, and North Myrtle Beach, is $541,287. Higher limits apply for two- to four-unit properties. Buyers should confirm current limits with HUD or their lender, as loan eligibility also depends on income, credit, and property type.

mainEntity.name: What FHA requirements should buyers be aware of in 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: FHA loans may allow down payments as low as 3.5% for qualified buyers, typically with minimum credit score guidelines around 580. FHA appraisals also follow HUD property standards, meaning issues like roof condition, peeling paint, safety hazards, or moisture problems may need to be addressed before closing—especially important for coastal homes.

mainEntity.name: Is 2026 a good time to sell a home in Myrtle Beach?

acceptedAnswer.text: For many homeowners, 2026 can be a solid selling window if expectations are realistic. Buyers are more selective, but well-prepared homes that are priced correctly and clearly communicate costs like HOA fees and insurance remain competitive. Sellers who plan for inspections and potential concessions upfront often protect their net proceeds more effectively.

mainEntity.name: Why are people relocating to coastal South Carolina in 2026?

acceptedAnswer.text: In 2026, many households are choosing coastal South Carolina for its balance of coastal lifestyle, housing variety, and economic stability. The region offers access to beaches, growing infrastructure, and a diversified local economy without the density or cost pressures seen in many larger coastal markets.

mainEntity.name: Is coastal South Carolina still affordable compared to other coastal areas?

acceptedAnswer.text: Compared to many coastal regions nationwide, coastal South Carolina generally remains more accessible. While home prices have adjusted over time, a mix of new construction and established neighborhoods helps provide options across a range of budgets, with ownership costs that many buyers find more predictable.

mainEntity.name: What types of homes are most common for people relocating to the Grand Strand?

acceptedAnswer.text: Relocating buyers in the Grand Strand often choose single-family homes in planned communities, townhomes near commercial centers, or low-maintenance condos. Many prioritize flexible layouts, efficient use of space, and proximity to everyday services rather than oversized homes.

mainEntity.name: Does the local economy support long-term relocation decisions?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Coastal South Carolina benefits from a diversified economy that includes tourism, healthcare, logistics, and professional services. This mix helps reduce reliance on any single industry and supports steady employment opportunities for residents planning long-term relocation.

mainEntity.name: Are infrastructure and public services keeping up with population growth?

acceptedAnswer.text: Ongoing road improvements, healthcare expansion, and broadband upgrades have helped coastal South Carolina adapt to population growth. While growth creates ongoing demand, many of the most critical infrastructure updates are already in place, supporting day-to-day livability in 2026.
